EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
FIRST ENERGY BURGER PLANT
RMP PLAN

Background

First Energy operates a coal fired electrical generation plant, known as the RE Burger plant, in Shadyside, Ohio.  Federal and Ohio regulations increasingly are requiring coal burning utilities to reduce emissions of pollutants from combustion stack gases including nitrogen oxides (Nox), sulfur dioxide, particulate matter, and mercury.  In response to these regulatory drivers, new technologies are being developed to control multiple pollutants.  One such technology is being developed by Powerspan Corporation known as Electro-Catalytic Oxidation (ECO®).

First Energy is working with Powerspan to demonstrate the commercial viability of this technology in the Burger Commercial Unit (BCU).  This involves a plant to treat a flue gas stream from one of the operating units at the Burger plant.  The system has been operating since 2004 and may operate for several more years.

The ECO process uses several different chemical reagents including 29% aqueous ammonia to help reduce SO2 air emissions.  Ammonia reacts with SO2 to form Ammonia Sulfate (fertilizer).  EPA Risk Management Plan (RMP) rules cover any process with over 20% aqueous ammonia and 20,000 pounds.  OSHA Process Safety Management rules cover aqueous ammonia solutions of over 44%.  Only EPA RMP rules apply.

The covered process includes:  truck unloading, storage, and transfer lines up to the point in the ECO system where aqueous ammonia drops below 20%.  There is one aqueous ammonia storage tank that contains 27,000 gallons (@90% capacity).

Burger site operations are also covered by other regulations such as the CAA, CWA, SPCC rules, OSHA, etc.

Overview of the RMP Prevention Program 

The Burger ECO process is considered a Program 2 site by RMP rules, however First Energy and Powerspan have chosen to implement additional elements of a Program 3 site.  Burger uses a management of change and pre-startup safety review procedure as well as tri-annual

he local fire departments.  Selected site response personnel are Hazwoper trained.    

Emergency response planning has long been an integral part of operations at Burger.  Regulations under OSHA, EPA, Coast Guard, and Ohio EPA have required the site to develop and implement procedures to plan for and respond to emergency situations at the plant whether due to natural disasters, storms, exposure to releases or harm/damage resulting from to flammable and explosive materials.  

Planned Changes

There are no planned changes in the aqueous ammonia system.
